review.title: An Algebraic Formalization of Forward and Forward-backward Algorithms
review.abstract: In this paper, we propose an algebraic formalization of the two important classes of dynamic programming algorithms called forward and forward-backward algorithms. They are generalized extensively in this study so that a wide range of other existing algorithms is subsumed. Forward algorithms generalized in this study subsume the ordinary forward algorithm on trellises for sequence labeling, the inside algorithm on derivation forests for CYK parsing, a unidirectional message passing on acyclic factor graphs, the forward mode of automatic differentiation on computation graphs with addition and multiplication, and so on. In addition, we reveal algebraic structures underlying complicated computation with forward algorithms. By the aid of the revealed algebraic structures, we also propose a systematic framework to design complicated variants of forward algorithms. Forward-backward algorithms generalized in this study subsume the ordinary forward-backward algorithm on trellises for sequence labeling, the inside-outside algorithm on derivation forests for CYK parsing, the sum-product algorithm on acyclic factor graphs, the reverse mode of automatic differentiation (a.k.a. back propagation) on computation graphs with addition and multiplication, and so on. We also propose an algebraic characterization of what can be computed by forward-backward algorithms and elucidate the relationship between forward and forward-backward algorithms.

metadata.title: An Algebraic Formalization of Forward and Forward-backward Algorithms

sections.text: Keywords: forward-backward algorithm, inside-outside algorithm, sum product algorithm, reverse multiplication, semiring

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In this publication, we propose an algebraic formalization of the two major classes of dynamic programming algorithms provided in 2001 / 2001. (One of the classes is called forward-looking algorithms, in which the order of calculation is consistent with the dependencies between intermediate values, but they are developed independently of each other.) The other term "forward-looking algorithms" includes not only the ordinary forward-looking algorithms (Rabiner, 1989) on trellises (Forney, 1973) for sequence marking, such as hidden Markov models (HMMs) or linear-chain Randomc © 2000 Ai Azuma, Masashi Shimbo, and Yuji Matsumoto. sections.heading: 2. Forward Algorithms

sections.heading: 2.1 Commutative Semiring and Computation Graph
sections.text: Unless otherwise stated, when the extended definition of a set, say, X = {x1,., xn}, is given, we assume that the listed elements are distinguished in pairs (xi 6 = xj for i = j in other words) and that therefore the definition of all non-negative integers and the set of all positive integers is not defined. In this section, we will first present some notations referring to directed acyclic graphs (dags) and then definitions related to the theory of semirroring. They are combined to formalize a model of compilation via a commutative semiring. In this paper, parallel arcs are allowed in dags. Therefore, the Arc-Set E of a dag G = (V, E) is a set of elements equipped with the head function: E → V and the tail-tail-tail → → tail-tail-tail-tail-E (V to a tail-tail-tail-tail = V).

sections.heading: 2.2 Commutative Semiring Computation Graph Parametrized by Monoid Homomorphism
sections.text: Our goal in this subsection is to explain another aspect of modularity offered by an algebraic abstraction that has not been described in the past. If an additional condition is imposed on the other side of an arithmetic diagram (G, op, S), the values of the forward variables of the arithmetic diagram can be presented as equivalent to a form that is changed "globally" from the original form (3). sections.heading: 2.3 Tensor Product of Semialgebras for Forward Algorithms
sections.text: The goal of this subsection is to find a systematic way to "composition" a new parameterized calculation graph. In short, our contribution in this subsection is to show algebraic structures underlying the complicated calculation, and to construct a systematic framework to build a complicated and difficult-to-design forward algorithm from the primitive and easyto design algorithms. To illustrate our motivation, let us present the calculation with the second expectation (Li and Eisner, 2009).

sections.heading: 3. Forward-backward Algorithms
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Backward Invariants and Forward-backward Algorithms
sections.text: The object of this section is to answer the question "what can be calculated by forward and backward algorithms." sections.heading: 3.2 Conditions Favoring Forward-backward Algorithms
sections.text: This conclusion naturally raises the following question: "Why or when are the conditions fulfilled in many common machine learning tasks?" This question is answered in this section. (Condition 1) In fact, there are a number of conditions to make forward-looking algorithms considerably more advantageous than forward-looking algorithms. (G, op, M, F) we specify the f -parameterized variables of the calculation, and (G, op, op, BC 1 S, gi) (i = 1, n) we specify the ggi-parameterized variables of the calculation, and (G, op, BC 1 S, i = 1,.) we specify the ggi-parameterized variables of the calculation.

sections.heading: 3.3 Checkpoints for Forward-backward Algorithms
sections.text: The technique is based on so-called checkpoints. When executing an instance of forward-backward algorithms, the values of the forward variables of a calculation graph are not necessarily stored in each element of V-E during the forward run. Instead, they are stored in the elements of some subsets of V-E called checkpoints, and then necessary values of the forward variables in the reverse run are not necessarily recalculated from stored values near them. One of the obvious good candidates for checkpoints is V. Forward variables are defined on V-E for technical reasons, but the values of a forward-variable on E are not necessarily stored in the forward run of forward-backward algorithms. Instead, the value of a forward variable on each arc can be recalculated.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: The formalization consists of (1) a unified abstraction of each calculation consisting of a finite number of additions and / or multiplications, which is sufficient to support the development of unified formalization of algorithms, and (2) an algebraic characterization of algorithms underlying complicated forward algorithms. Although we present only two pseudo-codes to construct complicated and difficult-to-design forward algorithms in this paper, they subsume a wide range of existing algorithms due to their versatility.

The formalization presented in this paper not only subsumes a wide range of existing algorithms but also extends them to an infinite number of their variants by using Framework 1 described in Section 2.
For example, consider the discussion in Eisner (2016). He has pointed out that the inside-outside algorithm can be derived by back propagation.

For example, consider the discussion in Eisner (2016). He has pointed out that the inside-outside algorithm can be derived by back propagation. The derivation is automatic as the reverse mode of AD can be automatically derived from computation on the underlying computation graph. However, his discussion is limited to the context of parsing. Moreover, the probability distribution is assumed to be log-linear because his discussion is based on the fact that the partition function of a log-linear distribution is also its moment generating function. In contrast, our formalization appears to show the possibility that the discussion in Eisner (2016) can be generalized to much wider contexts.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we propose an algebraic formalization of the two important classes of dynamic programming algorithms called forward and forward-backward algorithms. They are generalized extensively in this study so that a wide range of other existing algorithms is subsumed. Forward algorithms generalized in this study subsume the ordinary forward algorithm on trellises for sequence labeling, the inside algorithm on derivation forests for CYK parsing, a unidirectional message passing on acyclic factor graphs, the forward mode of automatic differentiation on computation graphs with addition and multiplication, and so on. In addition, we reveal algebraic structures underlying complicated computation with forward algorithms. By the aid of the revealed algebraic structures, we also propose a systematic framework to design complicated variants of forward algorithms. Forwardbackward algorithms generalized in this study subsume the ordinary forward-backward algorithm on trellises for sequence labeling, the inside-outside algorithm on derivation forests for CYK parsing, the sum-product algorithm on acyclic factor graphs, the reverse mode of automatic differentiation (a.k.a. back propagation) on computation graphs with addition and multiplication, and so on. We also propose an algebraic characterization of what can be computed by forward-backward algorithms and elucidate the relationship between forward and forward-backward algorithms.
metadata.creator: TeX
